P. 777.INTSRNATIONAL ECOKOMIC PC SITION.Note submittedLby. the Italian,le1egation on theReconstruction of fie many.(Circulated for information in connection with the decision of the Supreme Council on February 23rd,1920), ish TextAs a result of the enquiry into the economic situation of Europe, the Conference is in complete agreement on three points, with regard to Germany:- I(a) as to the economic solidarity of all the European countries:(b) as to the necessity, both in the interest of Europe and of Germany, of again setting in motion as early as possible the productive activity of Germany herself.(c) as to the necessity of fixing, as soon as possible, the' indemnity due from Germany, recognising that the position of Germany and of the whole of Europe will improve., provided that the indemnity is fixed, in a spirit of moderation, at an amount which may be explicitly accepted as suitable by Germany, and which may leave to her a margin sufficient to allow of the recenstitution and the ' freedom cf the national wealth. ./This is a primary question for Germany, as well as for the victorious countries and Europe in general. If all tho wealth of Germany is mortgaged by the indemnify, it is evident that only the victorious nations are closely interested in providing the means necessary for the life of Germany.But, the victorious countries are not in a. condition to do this, neither an regards the supply of foodstuffs nor raw materials. It is therefore necessary to place Germany in a position to provide these for herself cut of her $*ai resources.^ by having recourse to credit. From this follows tho necessity of'postponing tho collection of the indemnities, i.e. the advisability of giving priority to the mortgages asked for by those neutral countries, which may be disposed to give credit to Germany. I.236In this case, also, Germany's capacity for credit,would"h^ .j certainly greatly increased,, if the "indemnity vcould now ho definitely sottlod. But. if one would view the problem of the German economic situation and alleviate, at the same tine, the condition of the victorious countries, it is necessary'that these latter should permit Germany to mortgage, with a right of priority even over the indemnities themselves, all tho se.-. goods-and" " sources of revenue which, by the 50untri.es giving credit, may be regarded as sufficient to guarantee a loan to be granted under the solo signature of Germany.Tho victorious countries should simply give their consent to this transaction, which would bo used by Germany for the ends indicated by the Allies and with their moral support, By acting thus, an evident proof would be given to the world that Europe is really prepared to place herself under Peace conditions^One might hope also that Germany would be able to obtain, under the binding force of effective guarantees, a loan which would, provide, not only for her immediate needs, but also enable her to make to the victorious countries advances on tho indemnities owing to thorn* Germany should, with the consent of the Reparations Commission, be able to negotiate loans in the united States, the Argentine, Holland, the Scandinavian countries and in Spain, in tho currency of those countries, while undertaking also, if any of the said countries require this "condition, to use the sums subscribed only for purchases of raw materials or necessary foodstuffs in such countries.In the case of the creditor countries desiring to appoint a Commission of Control, with the participation of the lending countries and of the victorious nations, with the object of guaranteeing to them priority in tho reimbursement of the sums lent under the signature of Germany, the victorious countries should accept this condition, 237If this transaction should succeed, Europe would be placed in the position of having American money available, and, thus, even the victorious countries would reap an advantage, as also the neutral countries of Europe. In this way, one would gain the participation of America and of the neutral countries in the reconstruction of the productive activity of.-the other European countries.The mode of the issue of the loan is of secondary importance. It is clear that the conditions of the loan must be attractive, One might suggest a bund redeemable within 30 or 40 years, issued considerably below par, e,g,, 60-6^ and with a remunerative interest, say, ffi.The Reparations Commission could be entrusted with the examination of this proposal in all its details, in agreement with the German Government.Therefore, the Conference recognises(a) The necessity of supplying Germany with the meansabsolutely indispensable to the resumption of her industrial activity; in the interest both of Europe and of Germany herself.. nevertheless(b) The urgent necessity/of fixing the indemnity duefrom Germany, in a spirit of moderation, in accordance with the "forfait" system accepted by the German Government, if this Bystem would result in a more rapid solution. In any case,the Conference recognises the urgency of fixing a maximum for the indemnity.(c) The advisability of placing Germany in a position to avail herself of credit on the markets of America and of neutral countries. It recognises, with this end in view, the advisability of agreeing to a priority of guarantee on German resources, in favour of the organisation or of the countries which give craiit, while declaring itself to be prepared, if such a condition should be required to partici-pate in a Commission of Control for a redemption guarantee and the priority of credit. (d) The referring to the Reparations Comission of the necessary decisions, with the consent of the - German Government, for the carrying out of the credit transactions. 233POT OH TEXT.Conine result at de 11 exam en de la situation ccononiquo en Europe, la Conference s'est trouvee complet eroent d'accord, au sujet de 1'Allemagne, sur trois points:(a) sur la solidarity economique de tous les Pays d'H!europe:(b) sur la necessite.,. dans l'interet de 1'Europe et de 1'Allemagne, de renett-re en exerciae au plus tot possible 1'activite productive do 1'Allemagne meme;(c) sur la necessite d!etablirj au plus tot possible, l'in-demnite due par 1'Alleraagne, en reconnaissant que la situation de 1'Allemagno meme et de 1'Europe entiere sera meiHeure autant que 1'indefinite sera fixee avec un espri4^ de moderation dans un nontant qui soit explicitement acoepte comme convenable par 1'Allenagne, et qui lui laisso un marge pour lui rendre possible la reconstitutd.cn et 1 'affranchisesement de la richesse nationnalo.Ce^t une question prejudioielle pour l'Allemagnc, comme pour les pays1 vainqueuam et pour 1'Kurope.
